citation.article-title: Micrococcus lactis sp. nov., isolated from dairy industry waste
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Micrococcus lactis sp. nov.
Micrococcus lactis (lac′tis. L. gen. n. lactis from milk, pertaining to the isolation source ‘dairy waste’).
Cells are cocci with diameter of about 1.0 µm, stain Gram-positive, are non-motile and strictly aerobic.
Growth is observed between temperatures of 10 and 40 °C but not at 42 °C and between pH 4.5 and 9.5, the optimum being 7.5.
Growth occurs with between 0 and 4 % NaCl.
No growth is observed on MacConkey agar.
Catalase-positive but oxidase-negative.
Exhibits urease activity.
Cannot hydrolyse starch, aesculin or Tweens 20, 40, 60 or 80.
Positive in the Vitek2 system (bioMérieux) for leucine, alanine, l-proline, tyrosine and l-aspartate arylamidases but negative for ala-phe-pro arylamidase.
Positive for α-glucosidase but negative for arginine dihydrolase, β-glucuronidase, β-galactopyranosidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase-mannosidase, phosphatase, and arginine dihydrolase.
Exhibits l-lactate alkalinization.
Cannot utilize d-ribose, raffinose, cyclodextrin, d-sorbitol, lactose, d-mannitol, salicin, d-mannose, sucrose, trehalose, N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, methyl β-d-glucopyranoside, d-galactose or pullulan.
Sensitive to novobiocin, optochin, polymyxin and bacitracin.

Positive for oxidization of the following substrates in Biolog plates: acetate, dextrin, α-hydroxybutyric acid, glycerol, inosine, lactate, pyruvic acid, pyruvic acid methyl ester, l-pyroglutamic acid, adenosine, maltose, maltotriose, α-ketovaleric acid, d-ribose, sucrose, succinamic acid, succinic acid, succinic acid monomethyl ester, turanose, Tween 40, Tween 80 and glycerol.

Cannot oxidize α-cyclodextrin, β-cyclodextrin, inulin, mannan, N-acetyl-β-d-mannosamine, l-arabinose, d-arabitol, arbutin, amygdalin, cellobiose, d-fructose, l-fucose, glycogen, d-galactose, d-galacturonic acid, gentiobiose, d-glucose 6-phosphate, d-gluconic acid, myo-inositol, α-lactose, lactulose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, melezitose, melibiose, methyl α-d-galactoside, methyl β-d-galactoside, 3-methyl-d-glucose, methyl α-d-glucoside, methyl β-d-glucoside, methyl α-d-mannoside, palatinose, d-psicose, salicin, sedoheptulosan, d-sorbitol, stachyose, d-tagatose, xylitol, γ-hydroxybutyric acid, d-lactic acid methyl ester, thymidine 5′-monophosphate, lactamide, d-malic acid, l-alaninamide, d-alanine, l-alanine, glycyl l-glutamic acid, putrescine, adenosine 5′-monophosphate, d-glucose 6-phosphate, uridine 5′-monophosphate, d-fructose 6-phosphate or α-d-glucose 1-phosphate.
The cell wall peptidoglycan of the type strain is type A4α with l-Lys-Asp.
The polar lipid pattern includes DPG, PG, PI, PC, an unknown phospholipid and two unknown glycolipids.
The predominant menaquinone is MK-8(H2).
The major cellular fatty acids are ai-C15 : 0, i-C16 : 1 H, i-C15 : 0 and ai-C17 : 1ω9c.
The G+C content of the genomic DNA of the type strain is 68.0 mol%.
The type strain, DW152T ( = MTCC10523T = DSM 23694T), was isolated from dairy industry waste.
